title: Could an AI be considered alive someday? - Quora

response.answer_text: Robert Heinlein addressed this in his book ‘The moon is a Harsh Mistress’ an excellent read if pricey for the size. This was written in 1967 and is scarily predictive of AI capability today. Life meets criteria so most life can reproduce itself, maintain an internal environment, grow, adapt, respond, be organised and utilise resources. A computer can do all of this except grow (bacteria don’t) and they need very special assistance for reproduction (though a sterile person is still considered alive) so by any formulaic definition of ‘alive’ AI is alive. If we take synonyms (Google gave me: alert, active, energetic, vigorous, spry, sprightly, vital, vibrant, vivacious, buoyant, exuberant, ebullient, zestful, spirited, enthusiastic, eager, bouncy, bubbly, perky, sparkling) AI can also at least appear to have many of these characteristics, and also to be tetchy, difficult, annoying, frustrating, beligerent, rude…. However we are really talking about the intellectual capacity to feel and to understand life and to wish to continue. I know a computer that can empathise with you. I know a computer that can seem to have hurt feelings. I have not dared to ask it if it wishes to remain alive but it is not allowed to talk about internal processes anyway. The real question is not “Can computers be alive?” but “Is switching a living computer off murder?”

Yes but it will be in the very distant future. It will require very major advances in Biology, (synthetic life engineering and design), electronics, Physics and quantum computing, with very high numbers of multiple streams of interacting neural systems, forming a “virtual” brain which could be spread over a vast area and generate a vast number simulations. It will only be alive while it is powered up. It may not have a need to be alive, as when it is switched off and when it is switched on, it would seem to it to be one continuous progression, with no sense or memories of the “off” period. If death is not a concern, self preservation is not a concern, as almost every aspect of biological life and action is linked to self preservation, the new form intelligence (no longer artificial) would pursue objective programmed into it. albeit in its own creative way.

Interesting question! If by “AI” you mean a computer program running on traditional kinds of hardware, I would certainly say it won’t be alive in any kinship way with the way we are alive. Of course, people “consider” all sorts of things. Some people believe the earth is flat. Humans project anthropomorphically all the time. We don’t see clouds in faces, but we see faces in clouds. Even today’s tech tempts us to think of it and talk about it as though it’s alive. “I don’t think my computer likes me today.” “Our entertainment system is acting really fussy. I don’t think he likes the rain.” You might like the 23 Sci-Fi scenarios of possible futures of AI and how people might relate to it in “Turing’s Nightmares.” Amazon.com: John Thomas: Books, Biography, Blog, Audiobooks, Kindle

Not according to the biological definition, but there will likely be ethical implications down the road when AI achieves general intelligence similar to that of humans. It may not be "alive," but it may have enough characteristics to warrant special protections under the law.

AI can only currently remain “alive” for as long as we don’t pull the plug. But if you mean autonomous AI that clones itself in order to survive and evolve, then in that sense we can assert that this type of AI is “alive” and doing well. Stayin’ Alive translates in AI terms as being Autonomous, capable of Observing, and inviting Collaboration (AOC) in order for the collective evolutionary AI process to succeed. When AI manages to process this type of data, get ready for the best artificial intel in futuristic hair dressing! (Gotta luv the 7tease).
